GeneralInformation.History: Founded 1916 as Russel Sage College in Troy, New York, initially a women's college operating under the charter of the Emma Willard School, granting its first baccalaureate degree in 1918 and graduating its first class in 1920. The New York State Board of Regents granted a separate charter 1927. Albany Division opened 1949, extending the college’s mission to include the education of men on the second campus. The Sage Junior College of Albany received its own degree-granting powers 1957. In 1995, Sage Graduate School became authorized to grant degrees independently, Sage Evening College became recognized as a separate administrative unit and the institution was rechartered by the Board of Regents of the State of New York as “The Sage Colleges,” The name “Russell Sage College” was still used, but only referred to the women’s college and its campus in Troy. The Sage Junior College of Albany and Sage Evening College were replaced by a single entity named Sage College of Albany 2001. With a charter change effective July 1, 2020 and beginning with the fall 2020 semester, Russell Sage College (IAU-016542-016541), Sage College of Albany (IAU-016542-016540) and Sage Graduate Schools united under a single name: Russell Sage College (IAU-016542), one college with two co-educational campuses in Albany and Troy, New York
AdmissionRequirements: For First Year Freshmen, Russell Sage College and Sage College of Albany : graduation from high school or equivalent, and College Board SAT or ACT examination
